review_blob: Pours hazy golden straw-yellow out of the can. Nose is a bit thin and lacking. Actually represents more of a wheat beer profile in its aroma, with that sweet pie-crusty malt and flowery, slightly herbaceous hop presence. Not bad, just was expecting more from the heralded "VT IPA". Appropriate that this was initially an April release because its got that spring-day thing going on, the scents you get from airborne pollen and freshly mowed grass. This is a crushable brew to be enjoyed (ideally) under the sun. Enough legit hop presence from the almighty Citra to prop it up, but its foundation is still unapologetically wheat-esque. But man is it balanced and drinkable. This isnt of the knock-your-socks-off variety, but its a well-crafted brew that really wasnt made to be deconstructed, but rather enjoyed carefree amongst friends. A little sweet on the malts for my taste and perhaps unfairly represented as an IPA. Good nonetheless.

One of the only good things about late January rolling around every year. This beer is ubiquitous in Philly for about 3 weeks before it returns to its slumber. An amped up amber ale that has rightfully achieved cult status. Great head retention. Biscuity malts with grapefruit and tropical fruit hops. Nose doesnt adequately represent the perfect mouthfeel, balance and distinctive flavor of this beer. This is not a hop bomb by any stretch. It is a beer that perfectly features and accentuates the flavors of the hop profile, while using a lightly sweet malt backbone to increase drinkability. A perfect go-to, if and while you can get it.

bottled 11/11/14. Had a bit of lighter body being poured out of the bottle. Has an interesting aroma. Almost smells like a fresh Pilsner Urquell (no cat piss)!). Has that noble hop quality in the nose with some pilsener/German malt thing going on. Certainly a juicy fruit thing happening as well; maybe melon and plum? Flavor has a bitter twist that actually does not finish quite as dry as I thought it would. Does have a but of a prickly finish, though. Those resinous, bitter Neomex hops dont showcase a ton of fruit flavor; I get a bit of ripe cantaloupe but not much else. Lacks the depth I usually seek in an IPA; not bad by any stretch but not up to the standards of Sierra regular IPA offerings. OK so this is an experimental beer and a wild hop, so I was expecting something a little off kilter. If you are a fan of this series and like trying new things, go for it. Youll enjoy it but wont be blown away.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Wild Hop IPA - Neomexicanus

review_blob: Traded a Heady Topper for this one. Did not like the Haberno Sculpin but have heard nothing but good things about this offering. Dont normally comment on the pour or appearance but this ones got a nice lingering fluffy head that I can tell will leave some sticky lacing. Aroma is GRAPEFRUIT. F that is good. Unmistakable grapefruit with other hints of blood orange, juicy fruit gum, clementines and lemongrass. Flavor does not disappoint either. Has some of that familiar grapefruit tang in the front which tames the usual bittering hop bite of the regular Sculpin. Excellent balance in the finish, not too heavy handed on the grapefruit and enough of malt presence to not let the hops/g-fruit run away. Nice smooth mouthfeel, as well, which was a pleasant surprise. Worth seeking out!!

Really enjoy the standard Stone Smoked Porter so thought I would give this one a try. Smoked malt with nice rounded sweet notes from the vanilla beans. Has some freshly cooked bacon in the aroma. Lush, smooth mouthfeel with perfect amount of bitterness from hop profile. Almost drinks like a sweet stout if not for the smoky essence. Drinks pretty easy and has assertive and lingering smokiness throughout. Nice winter seasonal best enjoyed by a crackling fire

Deceptively light in body and color for a 9.4%, this beer was poured into a tulip and almost immediately you can detect the hops just billowing from the glass, Highly fragrant and dank. Resinous, piney hops piled on top of fruit forward grapefruit and tangerine. This ones an absolute onslaught of hops on the palate. Usually for an IIPA this big youd expect some perceptive and somewhat overpowering malt backbone to restrain the profile but this one doesnt hide its intent to glorify the hop. Could see how things might go south quickly if Enjoy By is not consumed fresh and flavors begin to morph. Firm bittnerness throughout. Bright, sappy pine flavors. Mildly chalky mouthfeel with a faint trace of alcoholic warmth. Not my every day choice but every once in a while? Sure.

Fresh 12oz bottle. Aroma is so fruity, with rounded harmonious notes of dried mango, pineapple concentrate, fresh berries and a sweet, understated malt presence that doesnt allow the beer to meander too far into one-dimensional juicy fruit territory. The "sting" comes from an initial wave of piney hops combined with generous carbonation. Interesting hop profile in that juicy, fruit forward aromatics juxtapose nicely with slightly harsh, dry piney hops. This IPA definitely has it all; finishes a little dry for my palate and would like the fruit forward hops to be featured more in the flavor but all in all a great beer.

Nitro version canned in August 14 at 6.9%abv. Poured into shaker glass with lovely khaki head and that wonderful cascading effect of the nitrogen bubbles contained within. Dark chestnut in color with a creamy, velvety texture. Not much hop presence in the nose, moreso malt based; lightly smoky, caramel, chocolate covered raisins. Mouthfeel is what youd expect, smooth and just the right amount of carbonation. A little thin on the back end, but in this case it just makes you want to take another sip because the drinkability and nitro experience is so fantastic! Lacks depth and complexity of the traditional Old Chub but you still get a great malt-centric beer. Awesome change of pace beer to have in the fridge for those days youre looking for something a little different.

Pours medium bodied with copper/red holiday hue. Sweet citrus aromas with clean, grainy malt bill. Light pine needle and cedar. Taste is unapologetically west coast, with dry, spicy, piney hops presenting themselves at first sip. Those hope provide a nice initial snap but theres an underlying sweetness and light citrus bouquet that brings it back to neutral. Finishes dry with pleasant lingering sweetness. Easy to drink and nicely balanced. Look forward to this every year. Seasonal classic.

Poured into tulip glass. Light bodied for APA. Decent pillowy head. Pretty sticky lacing. Doughy and citrus notes abound. Detectable and firm malt presence. Initially hit with floral and citrus notes that fade to an impossibly clean finish that isnt bitter or dry. "East Coast" balance. Little bit of a chalkey mouthfeel, and I like it. Attic must.More complex than most pale ales. This is better than I remember.

Pours a medium bodied, gentle yellow with a lil bit of a hazy glow. Has that barnyard funk-yeast typical of good saisons. Grassy hops, lemon pith, fruity traces of mango, white peach and strawberry. Taste is lively, somewhat peppery/zippy. Basement must. Very dry. This would pair phenomenally well with cheese, like a taleggio. Dry hopping gives floral and earthy element. This is well-conceived and nicely executed.

Pours clear, golden and lighter bodied. Aroma of pine needle, overripe pear, dried mango slices, caramelly sweet malts. Fruity and resinous notes. Flavor is bitter, biting and dry. Earthy, pine forward hops are present with what I detect to be an English malt base. Fruit notes in the nose are a little lost in the flavor. A nice go-to IPA to have in the fridge for a hop fix.

Lightly hazy honey/straw yellow pale wheat ale. Always like when they add wheat to the grain bill for hopped up beers (a la SUmpin Sumpin). Gives it that floury fresh baked bread quality. Highly accentuated by bountiful fresh hop additions. Aroma of tangerine, grapefruit, chalkedust, lemongrass, pilsener malts. Interesting choice of pils and wheat, malts that are not your usual suspects of IPAs. Dry, slightly acrid pils malts are subverting some of the fresh hop flavors. Finishes bitter and sweet, a bit fleeting. Its an experimental beer, but still a good product overall. Fresh hop ales are always a treat. Could definitely be refined and would be a stand-out ale.

Pours a deep, dark amber/cherry wood color. Decent carbonation and head retention for a pumpkin. Have been somewhat underwhelmed by Schlafly offerings, so was looking forward to sampling this much-heralded fall seasonal. Aromas of cinnamon, apple pie crust, rice pudding, clove. This honestly reminds me more of apple pie than pumpkin pie. A bit misleading, but I dont mind since it is quite tasty. Tastes like cinnamon apple sauce, baked apples (think...cobbler dessert), cinnamon stick and to a lesser extent nutmeg, clove and gourd. Fantastic dessert beer with a nice spiced, tingly aftertaste.

Highly recommended by sales clerk. Pours a golden, copper. What a head!
Juicy and tropical west coast style IPA all the way. Traces of grapefruit, pineapple and clementines in the nose. Noticeable firm malt presence with sweet caramel undertones amp this beer up into DIPA territory. Flavor does not disappoint. Everything that I am looking for in this kind of brew, although hops are a little more dank and resinous than I would have anticipated. Quite a harmonious libation we have here. Medium bitter, dry after taste. Wheat malt gives this one more complexity and texture. Beautifully curated hop bouquet, Again, well balanced and very sneaky and dangerous at 10% abv. Really good.

Pours slick, syrupy darkness. Black as night. Tan lacing and soapy bubbles. Aroma is freshly roasted, robust blend coffee beans. Burlap, vanilla bean, dark chocolate malt and wet cardboard. Perhaps this is the Bells take on the Founders B-fast Stout? Gently bitter and dry with notes of fresh ground coffee beans and dark choc candy bar. Nice full bodied beer that coats your mouth with rich, delicious flavors of roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Its been done before, but a really solid brew.

Pours relatively lighter bodied chestnut brown. Almost no head and what appears to be light carbonation. Something about this pumpkin beers aroma does almost seem fresher than most. Still has all the usual suspects in the spice category for a pumpkin ale: nutmeg, clove, cinnamon. Also has a honey/caramel like sweetness that may be the malt profile asserting itself a bit. This is definitely a more restrained and balanced pumpkin beer than most out there. Firm malt presence the entire way thru, similar profile to a good oktoberfest/marzen beer. If youre pallet is not yet burnt out on all the pumpkin ales, seek this one out for a milder, pleasant experience.

Pours a deep mahogany/chestnut color into tulip glassware. An inviting autumnal hue and appropriate for the imperial style. This beer has gained traction in the pumpkin ale market and the attention it garners is deserved. Pleasant bouquet that expertly straddles the line between sweet pumpkin pie and seasonal spices. Pumpkin puree essence is well honed and intermixed with cinnamon, clove and nutmeg. Almost has a Grand Marnier-like sugary sweet booziness in the nose as well. Dry mouthfeel with a slightly stinging spiciness complimenting the obvious sweet pumpkin notes. If there are any criticisms, maybe would benefit from less black pepper (or maybe too much cinnamon?) flavors on the spice profile. But probably in my top 3 pumpkin ales (non-stout). I do miss the old label..

Bomber from Beer Run in Charlottesville. $9.99 for wood aged DIPA seemed too good to be true. Pours an opaque, cloudy copper/mahogany with fluffy yet lively off white head. Massive woody notes in the nose! Poplar overtones with hints of sticky, tropical fruit-laden hops. Firm caramel malt backbone. Notes of plum and viniculture. Really excellent aromas that dont fade at all! Flavor is nice. A touch under-carbonated. Wood aging really rounds out the hops. Acidic and mildly boozy. The poplar really is the featured element here. Earthy, piney finish. I like it.

Initially tried this one in a cottonmouth state and thought it was terrible. Couldnt finish it, dumped it out. But now Im back for round 2, ready to give this one a fair shake.
Have to say that I dont historically like the British IPA.
On to my $0.02..
You can tell by the color that pilsener malt was used. Looks like a Prima Pils. Soapy head, that orange hue with golden tinges.
Aroma is underwhelming. Hints of some tropical fruit, but the booze is detectable in the nose. Malt profile is non-distinct.
Flavor is quite bitter, with a lingering dryness. Pine with dank hop resin. Its just too damn dry to really be enjoyable in my opinion. 
Could see myself doing 1 of these MAX. A little bit of a chore.
Might be more of a cold weather beer. I like the concept but for me I would rather have the juicy/floral IPA varietal.

Pours an odd lighter orange, a color normally reserved for pale ales, not pumpkins. Minimal head, somewhat fizzy. Aroma is overwhelming spice; clov, cinnamon, nutmeg. Pumpkin pie, sure. This had been done before, many times. And quite frankly, this doesnt hold up well to those others who were first to market and therefore incurred more risk in consumer acceptance. Seems everyone wants a slice of the gimmicky pumpkin ale pie. Taste is somewhat thin and overly fizzy/carbonated. Booze isnt masked terribly well. This beer needs work. But in the end, it is a pumpkin ale and for that I enjoyed it to some extent.

Session IPAs have their place in the warmer months during the daytime hours, where drinking a high ABV, full bodied beer just doesnt seem like a good idea. This Founders offering pours a light bodied yellow gold and exudes lots of earthy and fruit-forward hop notes. Definitely get some clementines, nectarine and grapefruit. Thin bodied mouthfeel with soda-water carbonation. This beer is a showcase of the marvels of dry hopping. Lots of delicious hoppiness packed into a smaller profile. Lacks depth and backbone compared to its APA, IPA and DIPA brethren, but definitely fills a gap for beer drinkers or want something light but wouldnt be caught dead with a macro light, shandy or hefe.

You either like novelty beers or you dont. I happen to enjoy them, especially in the porter/brown ale medium. With that disclaimer out of the way, I think this is a fantastic dessert beer if you are a fan of coconut. Its basically a liquid version of an Almond Joy candy bar. Big aroma of fresh, sticky coconut, milk chocolate, oak and vanilla bean. Flavor is full bodied and smooth, with overwhelming coconut and nutty qualities. One bottle is all you could/would handle, but a pleasant surprise.

Pours a burnt siena brown with highlights of red. Finger breadth of nice foamy eggshell colored head. Citrus and floral hops (mostly grapefruit/tangerine) abound in the nose. Molasses tinged malts with subtle hints of burnt sugar and sweet breads. Pretty dry red IPA with a chewy mouthfeel and lingering bitterness. Light, clean metallic after taste. Nice beer in a crowded space, but wont knock your socks off.

Pours as a pretty light bodied amber lager. Aroma of cereal oats, granola, toffee/caramel sweetness, mild astringency, with a touch of musty basketball gymnasium. Definitely has a German Oktoberfest sensibility in the flavor profile. Has that undeniably clean malt bill in the finish that only German malts can create. Need to really flex the tastebud muscles to find the oak, as its definitely not apparent in the forefront of this brew. I guess the real test would be to try this next to an archetypal German festbier. If you are looking for a good Oktoberfest lager, this is a good situation.

Pounder thats been in my fridge since February. Has that cold pressed coffee look, minus the khaki head. Aroma is toasted coconut, vanilla bean, dark roasted malt. Soft serve ice cream. This is a pretty light bodied and balanced porter with roasty deliciousness accentuated by the coconut that adds an interesting twist. Enjoyable.

Pours a hazy, glowing honey gold with ultra pillowy, puffy cloud-like head with nice retention. Some yeast sediment floating around. Aroma reveals what is undeniably a Belgian style ale, from their distinctive proprietary yeast strain. Other notes are rose petals, Juicy Fruit bubblegum, mild clove and other earthy spices. Hop element is definitely floral. Tastes like I just bit into a flower petal in full bloom. Peppery and spicy yeast flavors up front are eventually overcome by a pleasant hop bouquet. Nice subtle bitterness and dry on the back end. Good summer ale.

Bottle pour. Glowing amber with tints of auburn red. Im not going to lie, this smells like my first home brew, and not in a good way. Like too much charred oak was thrown into the boil and has completely thrown off the malt base. Hops are herbal, musty, almost head-shop incense like. Yes, I do get wasabi in the nose. SO at least points there for originality. Smooth mouthfeel. Sips come at you in waves. Sometimes all I get is a malt driven pale ale with citrus notes then BAM I get this wasabi-laden sip. Heat on the back is well harnessed. This is a total one-off for me. Not interested in round 2. Glad I tried it and kudos to DFH for always pushing the boundaries of what beer is and ought to be.

Pours a welcoming amber/orange with glimpses of that lighter cantoloupe-y hue. Aroma is juicy fruit and dank, resinous hops. Has a pretty mellow taffy and honey quality. Musty hops and an assertive soil and light caramel malt backbone define the flavor profile of this beer. Perfect amount of bitterness that hits you up front but doesnt linger.Im able to draw a little more fruit out of the hops with each passing sip. Lives up to its billing as an exemplary IPA.
beer_name: Cigar City Jai Alai India Pale Ale

review_blob: Poured into Sam Adams Boston Lager tulip glass with a copper-red hue and pillowy, soft tan head. Notes of vanilla, nuts (butter pecan?), fruit forward hops and toasted malts. Bready, pie crust essence. Flavor is decent: spicy, bitter hops Co-mingle with cracker malts to create a typical but above average "ruby" ale. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. A tinge metallic, but its not off-putting. nice balance, lacks that next-level depth but a good beer overall.

Pours a pretty full bodied amber-orange. Spicy hop character in the nose, amplified by the rye no doubt. Firm bready malt backbone is bolstered by a piney, resinous hop quality. Definitely has an evergreen, sap essence that is interlaced with freshh dough, faint alcohol (nailpolish remover?), and rawhide leather. Taste is infinitely smoother than I anticipated. A really unassuming quaff. Lingering bitterness but pleasant. Rye is not as pronounced in its usual peppery manifestation, but does show thru in the dry, grainy back end. The take home points are that this is tasty if you enjoy the West Coast Style. Piney, bitter, masterful balance w/ malt backbone. Excels in its mouthfeel. Nice.
beer_name: Hoppin Frog Hopped-Up Goose Juice Rye IPA

review_blob: Pours a mix of burnt orange, copper and glowing amber. Understandably light bodied, being a Session Ale. Nice soapy bubbles in the head. Nice bouquet of aromas: sweet bready malts, biscuit, both fruit forward and floral hops. Apple juice, peach, under ripe tangerine. Snappy, malt forward flavor. Some nice, juicy hops sprinkled in. Lots of good, full flavors that belie its modest ABV. Great session ale. Just be warned that this is more caramel/bread as opposed to the pungent floral hops being showcased in Go To, All Day, et al.

Familiar look for a pils. Muted straw yellow hues with a bit more head/lacing from the generous hopping in this rendition. Aromas of chalkdust, melon rind, sparkling lemon water, and crisp noble hops. Lively carbonation with tinge of lemon juice and overly dry finish. A bit on the acrid side of the bitter scale, as well. Give me a Prima or Pikeland, please.

Pours a deep brandy reddish brown. Not much of a head, fades quickly. A bit watery pour, not as much texture as you normally expect from a Dubbel. Aroma quite nice, though. Black cherry, lambic, toffee, raisins, prune juice, flambeed sugar, caramel malts, yeast-y. Very nice mouthfeel; good blend of effervescent carbonation and smooth, flavor-driven beer. Definitely getting toffee and brandy notes, and alcohol is well masked. I liked this much better than Grimbergen Blonde.

Pours a hazed out,clouded goldfish orange with some brown interlacing. Impressively firm off white head that was quite resilient. Nose is exceedingly aromatic: hay, mud, pungent perfume hops, lavender. Definitely some barnyard funk in there as well. Pretty complex beer. Nice effervescence, which gives way to a cracker and biscuit-laden malt backbone that was undetectable in the aroma. Has a bright fruity element as well: juniper berries and wildflowers. A nice deviation from the herbal/lemon qualities usually found in Saisons. Well done.

Light bodied, looks like a pilsner but with a bit more golden/orange. Nice frothy head with good soapy bubbles. Really fruit forward hop aroma. Fuzzy navel, pine sap, blood orange, passion fruit. Flavor is mild bitterness that fades to a fruity finish on the back end. A really clean, sessionable ale with virtually no flaws. Never thought you could infuse so much flavor into what is essentially a light beer. High price tag is justified, especially bc Im sure they are using a shit ton of oily hops in the dry hopping process to give the beer its distinct flavor.

Pours burgundy with streaks of fiery orange. Head retention consistent with the style, robust at first, diminishing to a foreboding and soapy ring. Yeast particles interlaced. Aroma of sweet and sugary yeast, bing cherries, tobacco, brandy soaked raisins. Toes the line between the Dubbel and Quad styles. Has a chewy, leathery malt body, somewhat grainy in the mouthfeel. Counterbalanced nicely by a robust fruitiness, think prunes and plantaines. Perfectly spiced and peppery with a hint of diacetyl. Great collab that drinks easy, is full of flavor and masks its potency very well.

Pours a rather thin bodied yellow-orange with surprisingly little head retention on a rather vertical and vigorous pour from bottle to chalice. Aroma is apple juice, white wine grapes, Belgian yeast, and salt water taffy. Or maybe thats the air Im smelling as Im enjoying this on a porch at the jersey shore. Initial flavor is a bit off-putting. A lot going on, but doesnt seem to be working in unison. Actually has a pretty woody profile with notes of funk, cider, tin, un-assertive yeast and cracked pepper all dancing around it without choreography. Not bad but very rough around the edges for a style that is usually proud with artisanship.

Pours a bright orange-gold, like glowing embers. Ephemeral white fluffy head, which dissipates to an archipelago of lively suds reacting with the yeast. Aroma of spicy yeast, coriander, golden raisins, mild clove and nectarines. Flavor is assertive, peppery Belgian yeast. Notes of banana bread, crisp perfume floral hops, pleasantly phenolic, plum-like fruit quality. A really nice take on a classic style. If the pepper notes were dimmed down a bit, this would be an absolute pace setter for American Belgian-style beers.

Light bodied, straw colored. Almost cider-like in appearance. Scant head with gentle fizz. Aroma is tart, apple cider vinegar, aromatic noble hops; musty basement beer, in a good way. Incredibly drinkable. Hard to pin down what exactly I like about this. Finishes with a bit of astringency, like a fine corn-based spirit. Finishes sweet with fruity esters. Gotta respect Jacks Abbey for putting their stamp on a segment most breweries would rather not offer.
beer_name: Jacks Abby Maibock Hurts Like Helles

review_blob: Predictably opaque cocoa brown, with a tan ring of head. Aroma of smores, roasted hazelnut coffee beans, cocoa powder. A little watery/lack of complexity in the initial mouthfeel, but finishes with a nice roasty, dry flavor, as if you just bit into a coffee bean. The oats impart more of a textural quality, a little granular. Pretty straightforward "everyday" oatmeal stout. Not lackluster by any means, as the ratings might indicate. Decent.

Had been eyeing this one for a while but held off b/c of the hefty price tag. Walked into my local bottle shop today and was on sale for $10.99 so decided to give it a whirl. Could see some sediment floating around in the bottle but still opted to take the chance. Great label art, guy looks like Brian Posehn (look it up). On to the beer. Pours an unfiltered, hazy straw yellow with some orange hues to boot. Good head retention that reverts to its original cm of depth with a good vigorous swirl of the glass. The Nelson Sauvin hop is the featured player here, with notes of cantaloupe, sweet garden herbs, dried banana slices and passion fruit. Mouthfeel is grainy and earthy. Hops taste of grapefruit, tangerine, soil. Quite dry. A bit of a pucker from the bitter finish. Nice hop profile that is a nice change of pace from the norm. Glad I was able to try it.

Pours syrupy, full bodied. Dark amber. Nice satin head. While cascading from the bottle, aroma was overwhelming woodsy oak. Complex, steady malt backbone with notes of oak chips, prune juice, vanilla bean, and resinous/oily hop profile. Definitely detect the 90 minute IPA blended in. Mouthfeel is sticky and sweet. Pretty amped up ale. Barrel aging works well here - Only complements the malt/hop co-existence without dominating. Warming booze. Floral hops in a battle royale vs toffee/raisin bread malts. In the end the malts win but both fighters left bloody and bruised. But the real winner here is me for getting to drink it. Another good one by DFH.

Hazy, amber/gold with a finger breadth of white foamy, pillowy head. A beautiful beer to the naked eye. In the nose, first thing noticed is the Belgian yeast - clove, apricot and peppercorn. A second layer of floral hops, somewhat grassy with a bit of a barnyard funk quality. Mild booze. Flavor is a bit odd. Honeysuckle, saffron, biscuits, rose petal. Big peppery note with a bit too much effervescence for a DIPA. Detracts from the hops, which are hard to pin down in this one. Would prefer if they omitted the "DOuble IPA" label from the bottle and just let the mind ponder the infinite space occupied by the Belgian Ale category. Overall, this is a fine ale. Tons of depth and complexity. Very good.

Pours as black as the coffee from whence it came. Single ring of tan head that settles around the edges. Large-ish yeast particles settling at the bottle of the glass. Aroma is steel cut oats, dark chocolate, blackcurrant, oaked anise, freshly ground coffee beans. Mouthfeel is a bit thin and fizzy, improves with warming. Flavor is big on the roasted and bitter element of the java bean. Not detecting a whole lot of oak character. Grainy and dry finish from the oats and coffee, respectively. For nearly $20/bottle, not getting the complexity and breadth of flavors I was hoping for. Am I missing something here?

Pours a luscious, opaque cocoa brown with yolky, tan head. Aromas are actually quite subtle. Piney hops ,a little lactic (chocolate milk), caramel and mocha. Does not assert itself with any dominant or overbearing flavors, but everything comes together nicely. Good balance of bittering vs. aroma hops. Finishes nice, clean, mildly diluted. Differentiates itself within the Black IPA style but does not come close to Wookey Jack, which is the gold standard in my opinion.

6 pack from Wegmans. Ostensibly an amber ale that reveals itself to be more of a honey gold when held to direct light. Some nice pillowy head with early signs of sticky lacing. Aroma is fruit forward, with a nod to mango, ripe pear, strawberry, golden raisins and honeydew. Definitely has a certain freshness quality with a malt backbone that is present and desperately trying to assert itself amid the dominant hop profile. Pleasantly bitter with onslaught of resinous, citric hops. Exemplary West Coast IPA.

Medium bodied chestnut brown lager with off white head. Interesting concept of a beer. German malt, booze-soaked raisins, sour dough bread, and floral hop bouquet. Very well balanced. Has a burnt, chewy quality to the mouthfeel. Nice bitterness. Crisp lager carbonation gives way to flavorful hop profile that finishes bitter and dry. Great change of pace from the typical IPA. Recommended.

Hazy, pulpy yellow-gold with thin ring of soapy head. Aroma of Juicy Fruit hops and faint blood orange. Sort of a cross between an APA and a citrus forward wheat. Instant bitterness and tang from the blood orange. A little grapefruit character. Finishes clean, tart and dry with good lacing. A refreshing offering for the spring.

Light bodied, pale orange pour with non-existent head and persistent bubbles. Aroma of unleavened bread, semi-sweet malt, light fruity esters. Lacks true depth. Zippy carbonation. Taste is floured dough, under-ripe banana, light chalk, a little metallic. Lacks the clean, crisp profile that is usually coveted from a German-style bier. Not good.
